Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 04:32PM LisaF wrote: Dear Rainbow! I'm so happy for you.  Yea!!! When I get my surgery for my bc, I'm going to have a reduction done at the same time.  (There is a silver lining in all of this.  I neverer would have done it otherwise.)    I  am a 40 DDD, but am worried that since I am large all over (5'7", and 185 lbs that I will look even fatter once the "top" is reduced.  How did this all work out for you? Thanks!
Posts.Title: Trying to stay calm RainbowRibbon9 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 08:12AM LisaF wrote: Hi Bluedasher, Yes, I got both sides done.  It makes for a longer recovery than just a lumpectomy, but it was worth it.  And, insurance paid for the whole thing as it was considered a reconstruction.
Posts.Title: So impatient bluedasher LisaF

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 07:39AM LisaF wrote: Hi momwholovessoccer, I'm a mom who loves hockey.  I'm five years older than you with kids who are 14 and 17.  I've been reading these boards since I found I that I had IDC in June of '08.  For the most part, it is very unusual for someone like yourself to have mets.  Also, the invasive part of IDC really means that it is invasive from the breast's ductal area to other parts of the breast.  It doesn't indicate that it has invaded your bones or organs. My advise after going through surgery and chemo is to keep your normal life going as much as you can.  My kids just had a big hockey tournament and I had a great time.  Wouldn't have traded it for the world. Hang in there!!
Posts.Title: IDC and concern about bones momwholovessoccer Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 11:15AM LisaF wrote: Hi Blue, I was also amply endowed, so I used this whole thing as somewhat positive experience.  I had a breast reduction at the same time!  Because they didn't have to worry about the cosmetic part of the lumpectomy since tissue was going to be removed anyway, I was able to have very wide margins of 2.5 cms.  Now just waiting to see if I need chemo.  Hope not!! Lisa
Posts.Title: So impatient bluedasher LisaF

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 08:28PM LisaF wrote: What a lucky woman your wife is to have you looking out for her!  I agree totally with wishiwere.  You have time to get all of the information you need.  IDC is slow growing, so  a week or two doesn't seem to make that much difference.  I went to Stanford for my 2nd opinion and they slowed things down and gave me time to figure out a plan of action.  Was told it wasn't an emergency.
Posts.Title: Husband of "Just Diagnosed" meinny7 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 04:57PM LisaF wrote: You poor things!  Now I'm scared, too!  I've just got two Taxol treatments left after doing DD A/C and I'm thinking raditation will be a walk in the park after all that.  I've been working just part time and recently just asked my boss if I can go back full time once chemo is done, thinking that radiation will be nothing.  Yikes, looks like I'm wrong!!! Hang in there, all!!!
Posts.Title: Please, please tell me if this is to be expected. HeatherBLocklear TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 10:00AM LisaF wrote: You'll have plenty of good days.  I agree, the 3rd and 4th days were the worst, as the steriods that gave me energy wore off.  By the second week I was feeling pretty good, and then the cycle would start over again, as I was having A/C every two weeks. Even on days that you aren't feeling well, you will be surprised how you can rally if something is important to you.  My boys play hockey and I didn't miss any weekend games or tournaments, even the ones that made us stay at the rink for hours on end.  In fact, I felt worse many times on the days I could just stay home.  Busy is better!! Good luck!!!
Posts.Title: Planning around chemo sherrimo NanaA

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 02:43PM LisaF wrote: I was told that you don't need to wash it off.  It should be absorbed if you don't put it on 6 hours before treatment.  I'm sure that others will let you know what they were told.
Posts.Title: Washing Creams Off for Treatments newmex1598 Valjean

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 11:39AM LisaF wrote: Hi BlueMama, Has anyone told you about a test called Oncotype?  This test looks beyond the size and grade, but also looks into the DNA of the tumor.  It then comes back with a specific number that shows the chances of reoccurance.  I asked for this test, even though my tumor was 2.3 cm, which pretty much automatically puts you in the group that needs chemo. It seems like you are on the border, thus your insurance should pay for this test.  (It's quite expensive, something like $3000 or more.)  I'm waiting to hear back on mine....
Posts.Title: Borderline for Chemo BlueMama Cindy1960

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2008 11:08PM LisaF wrote: Dear Member of the Club, I so agree with you!  I feel sort of the same about the SE of chemo.  I had my first treatment last week, and have had very, very few SEs.  Now everybody around me is telling me how tough I am and so on.  I'm just lucky!!  There are others who are no tougher than I feeling like (*(**& ) after the same treatment.  So much of this is where our luck falls....
Posts.Title: Christina Applegate my new hero KiminJax Daffodil

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 08:06PM LisaF wrote: Thanks everybody! I appreciate all of your insights.  I have decided to have the radiation done locally.  While the Dr. is new, he is going to follow the plan set out by Stanford, so hopefully it is the best of all worlds. Runner4life, sorry to hear about how radiation is effecting you.  Hope things improve!
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 08:13PM LisaF wrote: Well, I met with the "new guy" radiologist.  We're going to follow the protocall that I got from Stanford which is basically full breast radiation with boosts.  He was more willing to do the three week Canadian program, but being close to home, I don't think I need it. He did come up with an interesting question that hadn't been brought up at Stanford.  Because I had a breast reduction on both sides when the lumpectomy was done, he feels it will be hard to find the exact area to do a "boost" on.  All of the tissue has been rearranged, so there is no real markers to where the tumor was.  That is the bad news.  The good news is that without having to worry about the cosmetic results of the lumpectomy, I have HUGE margins of 1.5 cms all around, so maybe not having the boost won't be a problem. He did say one weird thing that freaked me out a bit.  He asked if I considered a mast., because if I did that I wouldn't have to potentially worry about 6 weeks of radiation.  What the heck??? Hope this is not a big red flag.  Not sure if he hadn't read the notes that I already had all this work done or what.....Yikes.  I told him if I was going to go that route, I sure would have done in months ago.  Can't imagine a new surgery at this point to not deal with rads!!!
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 08:14PM LisaF wrote: Thank you LuAnn! I'm sick of people thinking when I lose my hair that I will have so much fun with wigs, just like the Tv show Sex in the City.  I don't watch that show, but I'll bet  the actress didn't get chemo moon face, nor gained 25 pounds or lost her eyelashes and brows.  But I hear she got a great pink wig. Right.....
Posts.Title: Long, but need your opinion LuAnnH mom2acat

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 08:45PM - edited Sep 19, 2008 08:46PM by LisaF I know this has been talked about on this site, but doesn't Christina Applegate declare that she is cancer free?  I just have had surgery a month ago, but how do we ever know if we are cancer free? For you lovely women who are fighting mets, I bet this drives you crazy.  LuAnn, thanks for bringing this up.
Posts.Title: Long, but need your opinion LuAnnH mom2acat

Posts.Content: LisaF wrote: Hi there, I just finished with chemo on December 31st, had a lumpectomy with a reduction in August.  Now I'm looking at 6 weeks of radiation.  I love my caregivers at Stanford, but the drive is about 50 minutes each way. About 20 minutes away from my home is another facility that has good equipment, so I got a referral from Stanford to go there.  However, I found that the radiologist I was referred to has left and I have an appt. tomorrow with the new replacement.  Bottom line is that I found that he just completed his residency months ago and is brand new. I'd love anyone input on this question.  How important is the role of the radiologist?  After my consulatation at Stanford, I already know the course of treatment I think I want to pursue, so I would be using this local facility more for just the radiation itself.   Does the radiologist really do the treatment himself, or is it mostly techs that do it?  I'm also thinking that it might be worth the extra drive and just continue at Stanford, even though it will add an additional 1 and a half hours a day in drive time for 6 weeks.  But, then I don't have to hassle with having all the records going back and forth, which so far is a big pain.   Any thoughts would be appreciated!!!  Thanks,      Lisa Dx 6/10/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 05:20PM LisaF wrote: Thanks for all the great input! I think I will go with an open mind and hope that this closer to home alternative works.  Susan, I do wish I could do the 3 week program, but since I had a breast reduction at the same time, my original radiologist wants to do full breast raditation just in case a few cells got moved around.  If I could do the 3 weeks program I would drive the extra miles..... At least we are getting toward the end of the treatment line, considering how many months we have been dealing with this!!

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 01:44AM LisaF wrote: Hi Renny, What a great person you are to have gotten her insurance.  Just know that UCLA is considered one of the finest places for treatment.  I would be pro-active, but rest assured that you are in good hands.  At a free clinic the doctors deal with all kinds of things, so they can't really be specialists, but at UCLA breast center, that is all they do.  So, I would continue to research, but put my trust in the experts. Lisa
Posts.Title: Clueless and worried!!! Please help me.. renny85 renny85

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 02:15PM LisaF wrote: I had a lumpectomy and what they called a reconstruction because they also did a reduction on the cancer side.  I also had a reduction on the other breast.  (this was Wednesday, the 20th of this month.) My PS took out the drains the next day.  The BC surgeon visited me in the hospital later that day and about flipped out that they took them out so early.  Now I don't know if all the swelling and soreness around my sides are due to the fluid or just part of the normal healing process.  I would think that there can't be anything wrong with having the drains in for a while.  At least you know the fluid isn't building inside of you.  I wish I had mine in longer. Good luck! Lisa
Posts.Title: How long do drains stay in? HeatherBLocklear new2bc

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2008 07:06PM LisaF wrote: Hi Lisa, I don't want to be negative, but I would make sure you ask your oncologist.  Mine was aware of Dr. Quillin and pointed out that his degree (PHD, not a medical degree) came from Kensington University, which was shut down as a diploma mill. He said that doesn't mean that he doesn't know anything, he's obviously very involved in nutrition, but don't just take anything that is written in a book as total fact.

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2008 01:10AM LisaF wrote: Seebee, thanks for the clarification.  I will talk to my oncologist more about the studies, and hope that I get some good information, as I will be very bummed if I'm going through this A/C plus T if research shows otherwise.  Yet, this oncologist is very well respected so I do have some faith in him.  In my limited research that I did after your alert, I did notice that some think that there aren't enough studies to warrant stopping A/C.  I'll let everyone know what I find out, although it may be onesided from the doctor's view. Firni, as far as I know, A is always Adriamycin.  Hopefully someone will correct me if I'm wrong.  Also, in my reading I'm not familiar with anyone doing A/C and taxol aheck t that same time.  But, heck, as you mentioned, unless we have a degree in oncology, how  do we know.....

Posts.Title: Potential Chemo Question LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2008 09:03PM LisaF wrote: Gitane, Thanks forthe link to this article.  It really explains things in ways that are easy to understand.  I makes me feel better, especially since I'm already done with the A/C part of my treatment.  But, I will ask my oncologist about these newer studies. On another note, my oncologist, who is very well regarded at Stanford, was very strong in saying that the Oncotype DX was just one part of the puzzle.  The Adjunct! model showed a much higher chance of problems than my Oncotype score showed.  Also he noted things from the pathology report such as necrosis around the tumor, which shows that it is growing fast enough that the blood supply can't keep up.  So, here I am with the A/C plus T.  And, I have to say, with the drugs that help control side effects, I make it through the A/C part pretty easily.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 08:00PM LisaF wrote: I just pulled out my blood test record from when I was taking chemo.  My ALT was 35, which was considered fine.  The range they told me that was normal was less than 60, so your wife's number looks to be in the normal range.  I'm sure they will monitor it, but I was told that I could expect the numbers to go up during chemo, without a lot of alarm. Good luck!

Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 02:16PM LisaF wrote: Had my surgery on Wednesday.  I had a lumpectomy with what they call reconstruction and then a reduction on my other breast.  They took out lots of tissue.  650 gms on the cancer side and 400 on the other.  I had both a plasic surgeon and a breast cancer surgeon.  The problem with this is that they didn't seem to get along. For example, the day after my surgery the plastic surgeon's resident took out the drain.  Later in the day the breast cance surgeon asked why the heck the drain was already out.  Bottom line is that they are out, and it seems to me that they shouldn't be.  Did anyone else have bleeding under the incision after the surgery?   Would this still have happened even if the drains stayed in longer?  Also, nothing that I got from the nurses said I should be putting any ointment on the wounds, so I guess I shouldn't.  I feel like I didn't get much after surgery information as there wasn't one doctor officially in charge. Also, my fact sheet says that I can shower in four days.  Does this mean four days after I got home from the hospital or from the date of my surgery? Thanks!
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover
